title: Stefon Diggs, Minnesota Vikings scorch Philadelphia Eagles in rout
text:
Delaware News Journal

MINNEAPOLIS — The Eagles saw their happy Super Bowl memories from U.S. Bank Stadium turn into a nightmare.

That's because the Eagles couldn't stop Vikings quarterback Kirk Cousins, who threw for 333 yards and four touchdowns, and wide receiver Stefon Diggs, who had 167 yards receiving.

Or, really, anyone else in their 38-20 loss to Minnesota on Sunday.

It was the Eagles' first time playing at U.S. Bank Stadium since they beat the Patriots 41-33 to win the Super Bowl on Feb. 4, 2018.

In that game, Patriots quarterback Tom Brady had 505 yards passing. It seemed like Cousins could have had even more if he wanted. The difference, of course, was the Eagles' offense was able to outscore the Patriots.

That was not the case Sunday.

Yes, the Eagles' defense, particularly the secondary, was that bad as the Eagles (3-3) fell behind 24-3 in the second quarter.

Cornerback Sidney Jones returned after missing last week's game with a hamstring injury. It didn't go well as he was beaten twice for touchdowns. So was cornerback Rasul Douglas, who got burned by Diggs for TDs of 56 and 51 yards in the second quarter.

Jones gave up a 6-yard TD to Adam Thielen in the first quarter and an 11-yard TD to Diggs in the third.

And yet, even with the porous defense and a missed fake field goal attempt in the final seconds of the first half, the Eagles still had a chance to tie the game in the third quarter.

Trailing 24-17 in the third quarter, the Eagles got the ball back at midfield and drove to the Vikings' 22 and faced a 3rd-and-3. Carson Wentz's pass in the flat to Alshon Jeffery lost a yard and the Eagles settled for a field goal.

The Vikings, after a brief lull, got their offense back in gear and scored touchdowns on consecutive drives to put the game away.

The defense will have to improve dramatically for the Eagles to have a chance against the Cowboys next Sunday night in Dallas.

That's because Miles Sanders continues to be the Eagles' most effective receiver on offense with DeSean Jackson missing a fourth straight game. Sanders had a 32-yard TD reception and led the Eagles with 86 yards receiving on only three catches.

Wentz, who went 26 for 40 for 306 yards, with 2 TDs and an interception, tried two deep passes to Nelson Agholor during the game, but both were incomplete.

It was the fifth time in six games that the Eagles trailed by 10 or more points. This one, however, was worse than the others as the Eagles fell behind 24-3 early in the second quarter as the combination of quarterback Cousins to Diggs carved up the defense.

Diggs had 135 yards receiving and 2 TDs on four receptions in the first half alone. Cousins was 12 of 17 for 209 yards and 3 TDs.

The Vikings had little trouble moving the ball against the Eagles right from the start. They controlled the ball for 7 minutes, 17 seconds to open the game, and scored on Cousins' 6-yard TD pass to Thielen over Jones.

It only got worse from there as the offense went 3-and-out, running the ball three straight times. Then the Vikings again moved down the field with ease. The Eagles, however, dodged a bullet when Thielen missed getting his second foot in the end zone by a few inches, forcing the Vikings to settle for a field goal.

But the Vikings were only getting started.

The Eagles answered with a field goal before Cousins started going deep to Diggs. The first was for a 56-yard TD. Then after the Eagles missed on a 4th-and-2 from midfield, the two connected for a 51-yard TD.

Both times Diggs got well behind Douglas, who had no safety help.

That gave the Vikings a 24-3 lead with 9:31 left in the second quarter.

The Eagles tried keeping up as they responded with their best drive of the first half, capped off by Wentz's 32-yard TD to Sanders.

They had a great chance to get even closer when former Viking Andrew Sendejo intercepted Cousins at midfield with 1:02 left after Diggs couldn't hold onto a sideline pass, deflecting the ball into the air.

But the Eagles couldn't convert as Elliott's fake on a field goal went haywire.

It was a fitting metaphor for the Eagles' day.

Fake FG misfire

The Eagles ran a fake field goal with 20 seconds left in the first half. Elliott took the direct snap and started looking for a receiver. When no one was open, he started rolling to his left before throwing a short pass to Dallas Goedert, who was well covered.

The ball fell incomplete and the Eagles didn't get any points just before halftime.

It was Elliott's first pass attempt in the NFL.

If you love talking football, we have the perfect spot for you. Join our Facebook Group, The Ruling Off the Field, to engage in friendly debate and conversation with fellow football fans and our NFL insiders.
description: A Vikings passing attack that had been dormant for most of the season exploded against the Eagles on Sunday in a 38-20 win.
